ARTICLE.TITLE: South Waikato Blue Spring making Chinese feel at home
ARTICLE.TEXT:
Locals from in and around the South Waikato can't get enough of the treasure that is Putaruru Blue Spring.

Chinese now make up the largest ethnic group visiting Putaruru's Blue Spring.

The spring, along the Te Waihou Walkway, was once described as New Zealand's best kept secret and attracts thousands of visitors each year.

But Tīrau i-Site manager Garry Brunton said it's proving to be the most popular with Chinese New Zealanders and tourists.

STUFF Chinese visitors can't seem to get enough of the Blue Spring near Putaruru (file photo).

"Te Waihou through Tīrau is still our number one [attraction] and our biggest market out there are Chinese," he said.

"Local Chinese from Auckland are bringing visiting friends and relatives from overseas and Te Waihou just seems to be a thing with them, they just love it."

JEFF J MITCHELL/GETTY IMAGES Chinese visitors make up the largest ethnic group visiting the Blue Spring.

Brunton said the South Waikato District Council needed to make the most of it as the Chinese market was showing no signs of slowing.

"Trends are that by about 2025- 2026, Chinese will actually [pass] Australians as the number one visiting market from overseas which is absolutely huge," he said.

"We are seeing more and more marketing collateral from Tourism New Zealand and i-Site New Zealand in the Chinese language.

Evie Farrell The Jiuzhaigou National Park in China (file photo).

"May be [it is] something we need to think about for our district with the Te Waihou brochure. May be look at a Chinese language version of that because it is our biggest market and it is not going to stop, it is just going to keep growing."

South Waikato District Council communications advisor, Anthony Momoemausu, said the influx in Chinese tourists to the attraction was possibly due to its similarity with China's popular Jiuzhaigou National Park.

"Apparently the Blue Spring is known by Chinese people as the Little Jiuzhaigou because the colour of the water looks like Jiuzhaigou which is one of the most famous natural reserve in China," he said.

STUFF The Te Waihou Walkway leading to the Blue Spring (file photo).

Momoemausu said various sites in China, including Jiuzhaigou, also reportedly promote Te Waihou and the Blue Spring, if and when people are visiting New Zealand, as a must do.

He said while the council does not actively promote the attraction to China, it was working on a Chinese language version of its brochure.

"We have a translation service organisation that we deal with and we will be progressing this with some speed to get them ready for summer," he said.

"We have reviewed the English flyer too just for possible updates."
